title: Development of a differential treatment selection model for depression on consolidated and transformed clinical trial datasets
affiliations: Douglas Mental Health University Institute, Montreal, QC, Canada
Aifred Health Inc., Montreal, QC, Canada
University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada
University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada
background: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a leading cause of disability, and current treatment selection methods are inefficient, highlighting the need for personalized approaches.
hypotheses: Machine learning can effectively predict differential treatment benefits for depression.
A combined dataset from multiple clinical trials can be used to train a robust and unbiased prediction model.
The model will generalize well to unseen data and avoid propagating harmful biases.
major_findings: A multi-layer dense neural network achieved an AUC of 0.7 in predicting binary remission for depression, generalizing well to held-out test and validation sets.
The model utilized 21 clinical and sociodemographic features, demonstrating the feasibility of using readily available data for prediction.
Bias testing indicated that the model did not exhibit harmful biases related to ethnicity, age, or sex.
methods: Data consolidation and transformation from multiple clinical trials
Bayesian optimization for neural network architecture and hyperparameter tuning
